name: NPR
text: In an interview with NPR on Sunday, John Bolton said Trump frequently spoke with Chinese leader Xi Jinping about his reelection prospects. https://t.co/g0MOltzhA3

name: NPR
text: “I am just so happy that I have lived long enough to witness this moment,” activist Angela Davis tells @hereandnow. “And I think that I see myself as witnessing this moment for all of those who lost their lives in the struggle over the decades.” https://t.co/jH8qmXhYje

name: NPR
text: Kimberlé Crenshaw and the African American Policy Forum started the #SayHerName campaign to bring awareness to the names of Black women who have been targets of police brutality and violence. @hereandnow https://t.co/W85bZNjKwq

name: NPR
text: Commentary: "While it’s easier to ascribe racism to the heinous actions of a Derek Chauvin or even Amy Cooper, there are many ways to be complicit as sponsors or beneficiaries of unjust structures," writes @tmuguwe. @cogwbur https://t.co/Ds00DDYoaL

name: NPR
text:
Jasmine Guillory: "It has heartened me to see places like publishing houses, making commitments to ... do an audit of their staff and the books that they put out. So that's a first start. And then what are they gonna do? What's the recruitment gonna be?"
https://t.co/TtAb1haXfj

name: NPR
text: "There's a lot of just straight up hatred and resentment on the first record," says @phoebe_bridgers. On her second solo record, "I'm exploring just how quickly that all goes away with a little bit of examination." https://t.co/j9Sc6Udro4

name: NPR
text: Most people know the story of Tommie Smith and John Carlos raising their fists at the 1968 Olympics. But Wyomia Tyus made a stand at those Games, too. @OnlyAGameNPR https://t.co/FGK7YN8mSt

name: NPR
text: Harris is often the first name mentioned by Democrats inside and on the edge of the Biden campaign's orbit. That's despite the fact that Harris' own presidential campaign was a disappointment, having never even made it to the Iowa caucuses. https://t.co/6lakK4lQAB

name: NPR
text:
The world will use 6% less energy this year because of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the International Energy Agency.

But that won’t make up for losses from practices such as deforestation and wildlife poaching. @hereandnow
https://t.co/Zc8QZB5qt5

name: NPR
text:
President Trump and China's Xi Jinping spoke about Trump's reelection "frequently," former national security adviser John Bolton tells NPR.

According to Bolton, Xi lamented that Trump couldn't run for a potential third term — to which Trump "said yes."
https://t.co/mLhBUtabIS

name: NPR
text:
Someone left a noose in the garage stall of Bubba Wallace, NASCAR's only African American driver in the Cup Series, this weekend. Wallace had led the campaign to ban Confederate flags from NASCAR facilities.
https://t.co/WANxx95bTK

name: NPR
text:
Germany has flattened its coronavirus curve — dropping from a peak of more than 6,000 new cases a day to just around 600 now.

One tool they relied on: contact tracing by telephone.

The country aims to have one contact tracer per 4,000 people.
https://t.co/MjT47uAG23

name: NPR
text:
The White House is scaling back temperature checks for those entering the complex. Tents stationed along the north entrance to the building for conducting screenings were removed this morning.
https://t.co/mu6tbsNWbQ

name: NPR
text:
More than a month before Joe Biden's stated deadline for naming his running mate, Kamala Harris seems to have become a consensus front-runner to be the vice presidential nominee.
https://t.co/nlOdcoSRFk
